ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: i learned a lot about business ethics theories throughout various industries, like finance, pharma, and more. i thought the topics we went over were very interesting

I learned some basic history and theories from earlier discussions of business ethics in the 70s-90s for the most part. Stakeholder theory and shareholder theory as well. Overall, though, I felt that the class did not teach me anything applicable to modern day business ethics as we spent almost all of the class covering cases that were at least 20-30 years old and did not have any relevant analogies in the present day.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: we covered a lot of great topics and material, but i wish we went through some more present day case work rather than studies and legal cases from years ago.

Strengths: The class and the professor are very relaxed, grading is very generous, and many of the readings are quite interesting
Weaknesses: the professor was not great at facilitating conversation and mostly read questions off a sheet of paper, sometimes asking the same question several times. did not get that much out of the seminar itself. professor also doesn't give clear feedback on assignments though he is a nice grader and so it's not that hard to get an A
The content needs to be updated and revised to cater to modern business ethics issues.

The readings are very interesting and an important survey in the world of business law and ethics, however many of them were significantly outdated. Given how much has changed in the recent decade of business, it would be prudent to update the readings to accurately reflect what has been happening.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, i thought it was a really interesting combination of good business practices while considering the other end of it, being public relations with corporations and how either party is affected by certain decisions

It's not a great class to actually learn about business ethics, but if you want a really chill class where you can talk about it with other students, then the class will be mildly engaging. It's a really chill class and you don't really have to do the readings before class (there are over 100 pages assigned each class) and your final essay is about whatever you want. So it's a good class to take if you want something light.
I would only take this course if you are looking for an easy A. The material is sometimes interesting, but not consistently.

Not really. Prof Landis, while very kind, didn't engage with the students often, gave unclear feedback about the pros and cons of our work, and often repeated questions in the seminar discussion. It was incredibly student-led, and while I'm happy I had engaged peers in the course, it was not enough for me to feel as I learned very much.
